div.p: From William Kyle to John Kerr
D73/4020, unit 663, VPRS 3991 inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department Public Record Office, Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p: With referance to your letter of the 28th ultimo instructing me to proceed to Broadmeadows to enquire into the cause of the death of seven head of cattle belonging to Mr. The. Dutton, I have the honor to furnish you with the following information.

On arriving at Mr Duttons Farm I observed that there was little or no grass on the land, this Mr. Dutton explained, was owing to his having a large number (900) of sheep for a much longer period than he had intended when he purchased them, and that in consequence of this he had been obliged to feed his cattle on Hay and straw. This would make the Cattle more apt to eat any Green herb, which at other times they would respect;

The Plant / Salonum Nigrum referred to in Baron von Muller's report, grows plentifully on Mr Duttons land, more especially on the banks of the Moonee Ponds, here I noticed that it had been cropped quite short, the cattle were feeding on it whilst we were there, (I expressed my astonishment to Mr. Dutton, that he should allow them to do so) and the result was that in about half an hour after this three (3) more cows died close together.

Mr . Gralin Mitchell and self made a Postmortem examination on four of the cattle, the symptoms were the same in each case, and showed that death was caused by narcotic poisoning and from the fact of these cattle having eaten this plant - (portions of which were found in the stomach, by Mr. Johnston Analytical chemist,) I have no doubt but this was the cause of their death, — there were no signs of chronic disease in any of those we examined.
I have found the same plant in several parts of the country, viz. the Royal Park, Brunswick, Salt Water River, Merri Creek, Flemington Cattle Yards, Custom House Yards, &c, &c.

I would suggest that the Secretary of Agriculture be communicated with on the subject that information of these poisonous plants may be difused amongst the Farmers, & stock, owners, with a view to their consideration.
